results.title: Troll in Central Park
results.creator_credit: Gary Goldman, Don Bluth, John Pomeroy, Don Bluth Productions and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Stanley is not your usual troll because he has a kind heart and a wonderful magical gift. His “green thumb” can create flowers at a touch. Wicked Queen Gnorga of the Trolls sends Stanley to New York where there is little green growing. He takes refuge in Central Park where he befriends Gus and Rosie. Unfortunately for the trio Queen Gnorga decides to spoil their fun and lets her mischief magic wreak havoc in the Big Apple. With the voices of Dom DeLuise, Cloris Leachman and Hayley Mills.

results.title: Metal skin
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Wright, Daniel Scharf, Southern Star Entertainment and Daniel Scharf Productions
results.brief_description: After the controversial success of “Romper Stomper”, Geoffrey Wright’s second feature was a critical and commercial failure. However, this story about four young teenagers who find their only joy and exhileration in drag racing, is a mesmerising study of contemporary working class alienation. Set in Melbourne’s western suburbs the film is a hyper-kinetic study of the fractures and tensions at play in Australian society. The young cast is excellent as is the editing and cinematography.

results.title: The Lost weekend
results.creator_credit: Billy Wilder, Charles Brackett and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: This classic Hollywood drama scooped the Oscars in 1945 and it is not surprising. Ray Milland is an alcoholic writer who cannot control his binge drinking. Over a torturous weekend we see how the lure of alcohol has destroyed his confidence, his self-respect and his ambition. As it threatens to eat away at his talent, he comes closer and closer to suicidal despair. From a contemporary perspective the moralistic ending may appear trite but what is undeniable is Billy Wilder’s talent at creating a film which seems to visually simulate the terrifying perspective of a drug user’s imagination. Milland too is excellent as a man who is unable to reach the goals he sets himself. As a study of writer’s block, “The Lost Weekend” is both perceptive and illuminating. Jane Wyman appears as his long-suffering lover, however the book’s original narrative linked the writer’s fear of failure to his ambiguous sexuality. An outstanding film. Based on the book by Charles Jackson.

results.title: The White balloon
results.creator_credit: Jafar Panahi, Ferdos Films, Dendy Films and CMI
results.brief_description: This wonderful motion picture is the story of a young Iranian girl’s search for the perfect goldfish to release in her pond to encourage good luck in the New Year. However, when she loses the money her mother has given her, young Razieh and her brother seek their fortunes in modern day Tehran. This visually ravishing contemporary retelling of “The Red Balloon”, reveals much about the culture of the Muslim world. By filming through a child’s eyes, director Jafar Panahi reveals a world of incidental cruelty, a world which often rushes by too fast to listen to the desires of children. There is a darkness in “The White Balloon”, not explicit, but a sadness about the opportunities adults lose in understanding the world of their child. As in all the best fairy-tales, this is a profoundly humane story. The screenplay is by acclaimed director Abbas Kiarostami. Winner of the Camera D’Or at the 1995 Cannes Film Festival.

results.title: Mr. Holland's opus
results.creator_credit: Stephen Herek, Robert W. Cort, Michael Nolin, Ted Field, PolyGram Film International and Interscope communications
results.brief_description: Richard Dreyfuss plays Glen Holland, a musician who falls into a temporary teaching position at J.F. Kennedy High and stays for 30 years. The opus he composes takes second place to his great work, that of enriching the lives of his students as they pass through his class. This is not a film about a hero who performs brave deeds; but of ordinary people in everyday settings who strive daily for excellence in their lives. Dreyfuss is ably supported by Glenne Headly, Jay Thomas and Olympia Dukakis. “Mr Holland’s opus” is a sentimental, warm film which will uplift the spirit.

results.title: The Scarlet pimpernel
results.creator_credit: Clive Donner, David Conroy and London Film Productions
results.brief_description: Sir Percy Blakeney, Baronet, alias “The Scarlett Pimpernel” was the literary creation of Baronet Orczy. Sir Percy’s escapades during the French Revolution, where he and his band of young English noblemen risk life and limb to rescue the ‘aristos’ from the clutches of the guillotine, are vividly brought to life in this film made for television. Anthony Andrews is the dashing and elegant Sir Percy, Jane Seymour plays his lovely French wife Marguerite and Ian McKellen is Chauvelin, Sir Percy’s arch enemy. The costumes are sumptuous and the dialogue witty.

results.title: The Wedding banquet
results.creator_credit: Ang Lee, James Schamus, Ted Hope, Good Machine and Central Motion Pictures Corporation
results.brief_description: Wai Tung, a successful real estate investor lives in New York with his lover Simon. Wai Tung’s parents, wondering why he is unmarried, enrol him with a matchmaking service. Simon believes the solution is for Wai Tung to marry Wei Wei, an illegal immigrant desperate to remain in America; a marriage of convenience solving both their problems! When the news reaches Taiwan, Wai Tung’s parents board the first plane to the Big Apple so they can preside over the traditional wedding banquet. Suddenly a little white lie turns into a fully fledged farce as the simple registry office ceremony escalates into an over-the-top reception where everyone wants to kiss the bride - except the groom! Starring Ah-Leh Gua, Sihung Lung, May Chin, Winston Chao and Mitchell Litchenstein. Winner Golden Bear Best Film: Berlin Film Festival, Best Director and Best Film: Seattle Film Festival, Critics Choice Best Film: Sydney Film Festival. Chinese dialogue with English subtitles.

results.title: The Lion in winter
results.creator_credit: Anthony Harvey, Martin Poll, Hawarth Product Ltd and Avco Embassy
results.brief_description: Based on the play by James Goldman and winner of three Academy Awards. The story of Henry II (Peter O’Toole) and his estranged wife Eleanor of Aquitaine (Katharine Hepburn), is one of the most fascinating in history. Set in Chinon Castle in 12th Century France, the film centres on the royal couple’s remarkable love-hate relationship, which ranges from tender to tempestuous as they connive and cajole to decide which of their three sons will succeed to the English throne.

results.title: The Spy who came in from the cold
results.creator_credit: Martin Ritt, Paramount Pictures and Salem Films
results.brief_description: Based on the novel by famed writer John Le Carre, Richard Burton plays a spy who is unwilling to “come in from the cold” to assume a desk job. Burnt out, he takes on the most dangerous job of his career, stalking a dangerous East German agent played by Oskar Werner. Full of crosses and double crosses, this is a brilliant espionage thriller. The quality performances by Burton, Werner and Claire Bloom are matched by a tension-packed and well-scripted screenplay. The harsh black and white camera work makes a powerful statement about the futility of the Cold War.

results.title: The Swan
results.creator_credit: Charles Vidor, Dore Schary and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Days after the release of “The Swan”, Grace Kelly became a real Princess by marrying Prince Rainer of Monaco. In this film, she is a Eurpoean Princess destined to marry the Crown Prince (Alec Guinness). Princess Alexandra is more interested in studying astronomy with her tutor than marriage plans, yet once she sees the Prince, it is love at first sight. Capturing his attention, let alone his affections, proves difficult, until Princess Beatrix, Alex’s mother, connives a scheme to make the Prince jealous. Co-starring Louis Jourdan, Agnes Moorehead, Jessie Royce Landis and Leo G. Carroll.
